item.title: Greek Leader, Pressuring E.U. Lenders, Cozies Up to Putin in Russia
item.description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras shared a stage with President Vladimir V. Putin at an annual economic forum in St. Petersburg.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Iran Still Supports Terrorism, State Department Finds
item.description: The country has been unwilling to moderate its foreign policy in the Middle East or bring Qaeda members to justice, an annual report released on Friday said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: E.C.B. Agrees to Extend Lifeline to Greece
item.description: The European Central Bank has decided to keep Greece’s financial system on life support with more funding as anxious depositors accelerated withdrawals.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: People using ATMs in Athens on Friday. Greeks were still pulling out savings, as they have been in recent days, but the withdrawals did not appear to have escalated into a full-out bank run.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A German Writer Translates a Puzzling Illness Into a Best-Selling Book
item.description: After Giulia Enders investigated an illness that had left her covered with sores as a teenager, she began taking it upon herself to educate people about digestion.
item.category: Gut: The Inside Story of Our Bodys Most Underrated Organ (Book)
item.dc:creator: JESSE COBURN
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giulia Enders, author of “Gut: The Inside Story of Our Body’s Most Underrated Organ,” at her apartment in Frankfurt.

item.title: In Myanmar, Cash Remains King, and It Had Better Be Clean
item.description: Some of the practices of Myanmar’s dictatorship have eased, but a particular quirk persists: The country remains obsessed with pristine dollar bills.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Lets Citizens’ Fingers Do the Talking to Report Graft
item.description: The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection has added a new function to its mobile app and opened an online platform to allow citizens to report any corruption they spot.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Tombstones of relatives of Zhou Yongkang, an official who was sentenced to life over graft. A new app and online platform let citizens to report suspected corruption.

item.title: Vladimir Putin Speaks on Russian Economy at St. Petersburg Forum
item.description: Neil MacFarquhar, the Moscow bureau chief for The New York Times, is providing real-time updates on President Vladimir V. Putin’s speech at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Dozens Die in India After Drinking Tainted Liquor
item.description: Thirty-seven people had died as of Friday afternoon in a Mumbai suburb, and at least 25 others were hospitalized.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Chinese Stocks Stagger to End of Rough Week
item.description: Before falling more than 10 percent this week, mainland stocks had risen to nearly $10 trillion in market value, up from $3 trillion a year ago.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH

item.title: South Korean Official Says MERS Outbreak Seems to Be Easing
item.description: The cautious assessment by a senior government health official came on a day that he announced only one new case, as well as one new death.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Peter J. Li on the Clash Over Eating Dogs in China
item.description: Peter J. Li, a China policy adviser with Humane Society International, discusses the conflict between those who defend dog eating as a Chinese cultural tradition and those who view dogs as cherished companions.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Dog meat for sale at a market in Yulin on Wednesday, ahead of this weekend's celebration of the summer solstice with banquets of dog meat and lychees.

item.title: Britain Invites U.S. Official to Join Review of Its Military
item.description: To allay concerns in Washington about cuts in British military spending, an American has joined a panel that will determine the armed forces’ future.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Al Qaeda Denies U.S. Strike Killed Key Jihadist in Libya
item.description: It was the second such statement denying that Mokhtar Belmokhtar, the man behind the 2013 seizure of an Algerian gas plant that left 38 hostages dead, had been killed.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: New Jersey Man Is Charged With Planning to Aid ISIS
item.description: The arrest of Samuel Rahamin Topaz, of Fort Lee, was the fourth targeting a ring of young men suspected of sympathizing with the terrorist group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: Many Ask, Why Not Call Church Shooting Terrorism?
item.description: Civil rights activists see hypocrisy in how law enforcement and the news media describe attacks by whites as compared with similar attacks by blacks or Muslim Americans.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Bahrain: Explosives Seized, Police Say
item.description: The methods used to assemble the explosives bore “clear similarities” to those of what he called proxy groups of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Thailand: First MERS Case Confirmed
item.description: Thailand on Thursday confirmed its first known case of the deadly Middle East respiratory syndrome: a 75-year-old man who recently traveled from Oman.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Niger: 40 Killed in Cross-Border Attacks
item.description: Militants from the Nigeria-based Islamic extremist group Boko Haram crossed the border into Niger, setting homes ablaze and killing at least 40 people.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In the Footsteps of Other Popes, Francis Seeks Worldly Change
item.description: For generations, Catholic leaders have written documents on pressing social problems, but Francis’ encyclical on climate change is notable for its explicit call to action.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Pope Francis issued a paper on combating climate change.

item.title: Anti-Immigrant Party Gains in Denmark Elections
item.description: The far-right Danish People’s Party emerged in second place over all, raising questions about the role it could play in a new government.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: The leader of the Liberal Party, Lars Lokke Rasmussen, is expected to become the next premier.
